Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2008 02:06PM tamc130 wrote: I am having surgery on Monday and am so glad that I found this thread.  My PS would like to use Alloderm but has had no success in getting it approved.  Apparently they have gone through every last stage in the appeals process and have not been able to get it covered.  I spoke to my insurance today (BCBS of NC) and they said it is not approved as it is experimental and investigational.  We are now trying to prenegotiate a rate with the hospital so that my surgeon can potentially use it and we can have some control over the final cost to us.  Unfortunately if he needs to use more than we can afford we will not be able to use it.  Obviously I am very upset about this and wish I had known about it with more than just a few days to go before surgery.  I am, however, thankful as always for the wonderful women on this site who continue to be a great source of info to me.  Had I not read it here this issue was not even on my radar. Tammy

Posts.Content: May 30, 2008 12:44AM tamc130 wrote: Nicole, I believe that they can reattach the nipple during the surgery.  My PS initially thought that he was going to remove the nipple and remove the breast tissue through that opening and then reattach the nipple.  He said this would be the best way for me because my breasts were :( large.  In the end when I woke up they had not done that and had opted instead to make the incisions under the breast.  NOw with my fills the cancer breast looks pretty great because the scar is just about completely hidden under the breast - the other side the scar was up higher and you can totally see it but I know it is not as bad as it could have been so I am trying to not be too upset about it.  I know the chance for necrosis would have been higher by removing the nipple and reattaching.  As for scaring he said during the final surgery he would have been able to fix it cosmetically.

Posts.Content: May 29, 2008 05:40AM tamc130 wrote: Nicole - I reread your post again and realized that your surgery is to remove a benign tumor.  Not sure if this applies to you or not but before my breast cancer dx I had a fibroidadenoma that was quite large and my breast surgeon was encouraging me to consider something called cryoblastation (don't think that is spelled right).  They basically freeze the tumor I think and the body then reasbsorbs it.  In my case he said it would take about a year for it to be completely absorbed but it did not involve surgery.  I didn't end up investigating it because my biopsy on my other tumor showed that it was cancer and the rest is history.  Don't know if this applies to you at all but thought it couldn't hurt to mention it.

Posts.Content: May 28, 2008 10:15AM tamc130 wrote: I had a bilateral nipple sparing, skin sparing mastectomy in March after being diagnosed with DCIS in February at age 35.  My PS also warned me about the chance of nipple necrosis and I was completely freaked out that I would end up losing my nipples.  He estimated the risk at 20% due to the fact that although I was not a current smoker I had smoked in the past (Smoking ups the risk for necrosis).  He also said that if it were going to happen we would know within the first week.  I had two very tiny spots of blck scabbing on one of my nipples that flaked off within a few weeks leaving no marks behind.  The other thing that I discussed with him prior to the surgery was what the revision strategy would be if I did indeed end up losing my nipples and he told me that it would be the same as if I had opted not to try to save the nipple in the first place so I felt that in that respect I had really nothing to lose.  Hope this helps. Tammy

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2009 04:12PM tamc130 wrote: Just another two cents on mastectomy for DCIS - I had a bilateral mastectomy in March after being diganosed with DCIS.  This was the treatment recommended by both my first and second opinion doctors.  At 35 years old, daily radiation could have had much worse long term effects for my health than removing my breasts and that was one of many aspects that I weighed when making my treatment decisions.   Fear of a recurrance is also a very real aspect that people also weigh when making their treatment decisions and shouldn't be discounted.  Each person has to decide what she can live with and if living without breasts is easier than living with them and the fear of recurrance that should not be judged.  I wish your mother the best with her treatment decisions.

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2008 12:12PM tamc130 wrote: I had bm in March with expanders.  I had help for the first four weeks.  I also have a four year old so they mostly helped with that and with meals.  I napped some every afternoon too and they were there to watch my daughter.  I had help in the shower for maybe the first week.  Didn't really need much help with the drains - the first couple of days until I got the hang of it.  I am a very do-it-yourself kind of person and needing the help was quite a humbling experience for me.  I did not drive until the 5th week.  My doctor's said no driving for 4-6 weeks and when I started driving again it was very uncomfortable.  I wonder if I would have been able to do a bit more if I had been willing to take some of the pain meds but I just didn't want to be on anything after the first week or so.  I was up and around though within a few days and getting out of the house everyday to ride along with my daughter on her way to school and to pick her up, etc.  I think everyone's experience will be different but I remember right before the surgery getting very anxious to know what to expect.  Good luck with your surgery. Tammy

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2009 03:09AM tamc130 wrote: I had my exchange surgry in August and my PS wanted to use alloderm.  BCBS said they would not cover it.  They said it is specifically listed as a non covered item.  My PS said that he has never been able to sucessfully appeal it with BCBS.  In the end, we decided to prenegotiate a rate with the hospital for the alloderm and approved use of it with the PS up to a dollar amount.  I think the amount we approved was about $10,000 which I believe would have paid for a medium size piece.  I'm not 100% certain on those details because my husband worked with the billing office and I was actually in the pre-op before it was all worked out.  At any rate, in the end the plastic surgeon did not end up using the alloderm as he felt pleased with the result without it.
